4.44.text: that they had what it took

5.76.text: to win the toughest challenge in quizzing...

15.48.text: Tonight, we will find out who is to be crowned the nation's Mastermind.

20.00.text: This is the Mastermind Grand Final.

40.16.text: First in the spotlight tonight is Alan Heath,

48.24.text: an administrator from Kent on England Test Cricket since 1970.

52.92.text: Christine Harrison is an agency worker from Southampton.

58.72.text: Andrew Diamond, an IT consultant from Walthamstow.

61.60.text: His subject - the Seven Years' War.

64.00.text: Ewan Paton, a barrister from Bristol,

66.08.text: answers questions on the Ryder Cup.

71.72.text: His subject - the Battle for Berlin.

87.60.text: Hello and welcome to the Mastermind Grand Final with me, John Humphrys.

92.48.text: Tonight's six finalists have won their way through the heats

97.44.text: but this is where it gets really serious.

99.92.text: Only a tiny number of people throughout the nation

102.64.text: can claim the title of Mastermind

105.68.text: we shall find out who will be the latest to join that elite group.

110.36.text: They all know the rules, as I'm sure you do.

112.48.text: They get two minutes on their specialist subject

117.52.text: Five of them will leave empty-handed.

119.28.text: The winner will take home the glass bowl

122.00.text: and the right to say, "I was the Mastermind Champion."

125.52.text: Let's get on with it, then,

126.80.text: and ask our first finalist to join us, please.

164.32.text: and I revisited it at every opportunity

174.28.text: and the models, and the puppetry.

193.76.text: he really has to watch television.

209.36.text: and he's done so well. I'm so proud of him.

757.52.text: at the most important Gaskell collection in the world.

764.72.text: When people think of the 19th century,

767.44.text: the women writers they choose are the big three -

769.96.text: Jane Austen, George Eliot, and the Bronte sisters -

773.48.text: but I think Mrs Gaskell deserves a place amongst them.

777.64.text: I was drawn to her courage as a writer.

780.76.text: In those days, women writers were frowned upon,

784.28.text: and people like George Eliot had to actually write under a pen name -

789.28.text: she was really Mary Ann Evans.

791.08.text: But Mrs Gaskell, I feel, was very courageous in her writing.

796.28.text: She brings to light a lot of subjects

798.52.text: which women in particular were not supposed to talk about at the time.

803.16.text: It was a real thrill to be able to see the actual manuscript

806.44.text: of The Life Of Charlotte Bronte,

808.40.text: and to think that this was Mrs Gaskell's own hand

811.04.text: that had written it - all her crossings out and alterations.

817.32.text: It's quite something to see this actual manuscript in all its glory.

822.68.text: There have been some very good adaptations

824.80.text: of Mrs Gaskell's work on television.

829.12.text: It is a joy to us that your stepmother can spare you.

832.44.text: Now that there are so many little Smiths at home - four already.

843.52.text: in the Elizabeth Gaskell house in Plymouth Grove, Manchester.

855.60.text: because I feel as if it's really brought home to me

860.20.text: and I'm almost expecting her to walk through that door

871.52.text: in the sense that she obviously wrote quite a bit -

874.48.text: not just the novels, but articles, short stories, and novellas.

880.88.text: by obviously reading up as much as possible,

883.20.text: and I'm making notes on each book as I go along,

885.56.text: which is obviously quite hard work,

887.52.text: but it's quite a lot of fun.

890.36.text: I never honestly believed I would make it through to the final.

894.96.text: I'm delighted that I've come this far, but, having said that,

898.48.text: I would love to win that trophy.

3083.24.text: to indicate modified sounds, such as a grave or acute accent?

3089.68.text: A mechanical firing mechanism invented around the middle

3092.32.text: of the 15th century allowed soldiers to hold their gun

3095.40.text: with both hands throughout aiming and firing - which mechanism?

3101.04.text: What completes the lines from Tennyson's poem

3103.04.text: The Charge of the Light Brigade -

3104.48.text: "Theirs not to make reply, Theirs not to reason why,

3109.04.text: Which religion's sacred text is traditionally believed

3111.72.text: to have been translated from golden plates granted to the faith's founder

3114.96.text: near his home in upstate New York?

3117.92.text: Joan of Arc referred to herself as "Jehanne La Pucelle" -

3120.40.text: what is the meaning of "la Pucelle" in English?

3123.88.text: Ghost Flight is the debut adult novel of a British adventurer,

3126.64.text: writer and television presenter - who is he?

3130.76.text: In which of the Baltic states are Tartu

3132.68.text: and Parnu among the principal cities?

3135.44.text: Which chemical element has isotopes known as deuterium and tritium?

3141.32.text: What name for the meat obtained from deer

3143.12.text: comes from the Old French for "hunting?"

3146.04.text: Which wolf-like animal shares its name with a trickster figure

3148.80.text: found in the mythology of many of the indigenous people of north America?

3155.64.text: I'm afraid not, because we're out of time.

3163.60.text: No passes, Jim. You have 27 points.

3181.24.text: Well, I said this was going to be a tough battle -

3183.96.text: I didn't realise quite how tough.

3186.24.text: Let's have a look at all the scores. In sixth place,

3200.08.text: Joint first place - 27 points apiece and no passes, either,

3214.32.text: So, we have a tie-break, and that is the first time

3217.64.text: it's happened in a grand final - certainly in the years that I've been doing the programme.

3222.00.text: Now, what happens is this. I shall read the same five questions

3225.64.text: to each of the contenders, and the one with the higher score will win,

3229.96.text: and we are not against the clock this time.

3232.16.text: So, let me ask Jim to leave the studio now, for obvious reasons,

3235.88.text: and Alan, if you would please come to the chair,

3240.04.text: and I shall give you your five questions and I will not

3245.60.text: be telling you whether you've got the answers right or wrong -

3248.40.text: that, we shall discover in a moment.

3252.60.text: The burbot is the only freshwater member of which fish family?

3255.48.text: Like most other members of the family, they have well-developed chin barbels.

3262.00.text: In classical mythology, a beautiful statue came to life

3264.96.text: in answer to the prayers of the sculptor Pygmalion -

3267.92.text: what name has she been given in the post-classical era?

3277.24.text: Which novelist's 1992 book The Queen and I

3279.48.text: sees the Royal Family exiled to a council estate in the Midlands

3283.12.text: after a republican party wins the General Election?

3303.16.text: Which Welsh rock band released the album Futurology in 2014?

3309.32.text: Which artificial waterway was opened in 1894

3312.20.text: and has locks at Eastham, Latchford, Irlam, Barton and Mode Wheel?

3317.36.text: Thank you, those are your five questions.

3328.72.text: And now let's get Jim back into the chair.

3333.16.text: And exactly the same procedure with you, Jim. I ask you five questions,

3337.32.text: and you're not against the clock. Here we go.

3340.68.text: The burbot is the only freshwater member of which fish family?

3343.84.text: Like most other members of the family, they have well-developed chin barbels?

3354.84.text: In classical mythology, a beautiful statue came to life

3357.28.text: in answer to the prayers of the sculptor Pygmalion -

3359.48.text: what name has she been given in the post-classical era?

3368.60.text: Which novelist's 1992 book The Queen and I

3370.88.text: sees the Royal Family exiled to a council estate in the Midlands

3373.72.text: after a republican party wins the General Election?

3400.60.text: Which Welsh rock band released the album Futurology in 2014?

3408.44.text: Which artificial waterway was opened in 1894

3411.08.text: and has locks at Eastham, Latchford, Irlam, Barton and Mode Wheel?

3424.20.text:
- And those are your five questions. 
- Thank you.

3436.40.text: Well, at the end of that tie-break,

3440.68.text: Jim has a total now of 27 points,

3446.96.text: the Mastermind champion is Alan Heath.

3478.72.text: So you're not only the 2016 Mastermind champion,

3482.80.text: but you've also made a little bit of history

3484.96.text: because it hasn't gone, the grand final, to a tie-break before.

3489.44.text:
- What was it like for you? 
- It's pure hell.

3491.20.text: Pure hell! That sums it up nicely,

3493.44.text: but you're a worthy winner. Alan is our winner,

3496.68.text: but the search will start again later this year

3499.12.text: to find a new Mastermind, and if you think that could be you,

3502.96.text: then do visit us online at...

3506.60.text: ..and of course you can follow us on Twitter at...

3510.40.text: ..and do join us next time for more Masterminds.
